WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 404 July 1980 POPULATION AND POVERTY IN THE DEVELOPING WORLD A Background Paper for World Development Report, 1980 This paper analyzes the association between poverty and rapid population growth. In addition to reviewing the current demographic situation and the future outlook for population growth, it considers the following questions': W4hat are the effects of rapid population growth on economic growth and income distribution? How does family size affect the health, educational status, and income of individual family members? To what extent, and how, do low income, poor health, and a lack of education cause high fertility? Is the provision of family planning services an end in itself, as well as a means of fertility reduction?  The populations of developing countries are growing rapidly; the role of human resource programs in alleviating poverty and more generally in contributing to development cannot be considered outside this context of rapid population growth. Developing countries are like long-distance runners. In their race against time to eliminate poverty, rapid population growth is an additional burden, which regardless of their inherent strengths, slows them down. Moreover a quick glance at the race suggests it is an unfair one. The weaker runners are those advancing most slowly and already behind the pack; they also have the highest population growth rates, and are thus the most severely handicapped. In the following pages, we look more closely at this apparent close association between poverty and rapid population growth, and consider why and how the two are mutually reinforcing. By poverty we mean not only low income, but the nexus of conditions often but imperfectly associated with low income--lack of education, poor nutrition and high morbidity and mortality. A major point, in fact, is that improvements in health and education, in addition to their direct benefits, are an effective and relatively low-cost way to weaken the link binding low-income households and poor countries to rapid rates of population growth. At the outset it is worth emphasizing that, though poverty and rapid population growth are strongly, indeed as we hope to show, causally linked, neither is the sole determinant nor the inevitable consequence of the other. In particular, if we ignore the extent of poverty within nations, counterexamples abound. Rapid population growth has accompanied rapid economic growth in Brazil; slower population growth has accompanied slower economic growth in India and Sri Lanka. Elimination of poverty in a "reasonable" time period may be possible for a few countries despite their population burden--e.g., those with unusual natural resources such as the oil-exporting countries, or those already running fast and light due to prior development policies or a head start in the growth race. On the other hand, for the weaker runners, reducing the population burden is no panacea; more direct attacks on poverty and the problem of slow growth are necessary. There is no runner, however, for whom a lighter burden would not speed the pace; within every country, for any given resources, the depth and incidence of future poverty could be reduced with lower rates of popu~lation growth. We begin (Part I) with a brief review of the current demographic situation in the developing world. Particular attention goes to the shift over time in the association across countries between low income and high fertility and mortality rates. Part II is concerned with the effects of rapid population growth on the situation of the poor. These effects operate at the national level by influencing factor and product prices and the per capita availability of investment resources; as the poor are usually the last in line for jobs, school places and public health services, rapid population growth hurts them
 -2- disproportionately. They also operate at the family level, by reducing parents' per-child investments in health and education; since the poor tend to have large families, poor children are often particularly disadvantaged. The negative association between income and fertility is clear, across countries and across households within countries. Association alone gives few clues to causation, however; in Part III we review the theory at the family level regarding the relation between family size and family members' health and educational as well as income status, seeking to answer whether and to what extent low income, lack of education and poor health cause high fertility, the major contributor to rapid population growth. Part IV discusses population policy, with particular attention to an important component of policy, the delivery of family planning servi- ces to the poor. Reducing population growth is not an end in itself but a means to the larger end of improving human welfare. Provision of family planning services, however, serves both as a means of fertility reduction, and as an end. Illustrative projections of population growth into the 21st century follow (Part V), based on a set of assumptions regarding the future course of growth and poverty alleviation and the future family planning policies of developing countries.
 I. The Demographic Situation in the Developing World A review of the current world demographic situation yields five central facts regarding the developing countries, each of which bears on our overall theme of the links between poverty and raid population growth: 1. Postwar population growth rates in developing countries have been unprecedentedly rapid. Most of the increase in world population today is occurring in developing countries, now comprising about three quarters of the world popu- lation. In the now-developed world (Europe, the U.S. and Canada, the Soviet Union, Japan, Oceania), population growth has slowed to a rate below 1 per- cent a year. Figure I-1 shows trends in births and death rates for developed and developing countries. In the developed world death rates have fallen gradually and steadily since the early 19th century, and birth rates have come down more or less in tandem, slowing population growth before it could become seriously burdensome. Natural rates of population increase -- the gap between birth and death rates -- have rarely exceeded 1.5 percent. In contrast, in the developing countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America, the demographic transition -- the change from high birth and death rates to low ones -- has come in fits and starts. Both birth and death rates remained high until well into the 20th century. After World War II, death rates fell steeply; as birth rates fell by less, population growth accelerated. By the mid-1960s, the combination of still-high fertility and much-reduced mortality led to popu- lation growth rates well above 2 percent a year. In several countries of Latin America and Africa, rates of natural increase exceeded 3 percent; a 3 percent rate implies a doubling of population every 23 years, compared to 70 years doubling time with the 1 percent growth typical in 19th century Europe. Though birth rates are now declining, they are still high relative to death rates, and population growth poses for the now-modernizing economies a problem for which the economic and demographic history of the West offers no real precedent. 2. In the last decade or so, rates of population growth in the developing countries have been declining, even if very slowly. For developing countries as a group, the high point of population growth, when high fertility combined with declining mortality, was passed in about 1965. Since then, in many countries -- indeed in those comprising the bulk of the world's population -- a fertility decline began between 1965 and the present. Moreover, the rate at which fertility is declining appears to be accelerating; the recent declines in developing countries have been faster than earlier declines in Europe and Japan. Mortality declines which began earlier, in virtually all countries in the 1950s, have continued, but in the last few years the pace of mortality decline appears to have slowed. With this emerging combination of accelerating fertility decline and deceler- ating mortality decline, natural rates of increase have gone from a high of about 2.4 percent in 1965 to 2.2 percent today.

It is well known that mortality in developing countries has fallen more rapidly and at income and education levels lower than those associated with mortality decline in the West. 1/ Less well-known is that the same holds for fertility; recent fertility declines, where they have begun, are occurring at lower average levels of income and at a faster rate than earlier declines. The remainder of this section is a discussion of this shift over time in the association between country income levels and mortality and fer- tility declines. The purpose is to draw out the nature of the interaction between the prevalence of poverty within countries and these rates. Past and Future Mortality Decline Analysis of the mortality decline using country-level data suggests that until recently a good deal of the postwar decline has been due less to improvements in living standards than to the introduction of important new public health technologies; in this sense, technology has probably led "development," where by development is meant reduction in the incidence of poverty. For mortality, the major question for the future is the extent to which future declines depend on further development, i.e., further improvements in nutrition and health for broader segments of the populations. Mortality (and more generally health) is the result of the inter- action of three sets of factors affecting an individual's physical well- being: public health services which affect mortality regardless of indivi- dual behavior, such as malarial spraying and immunization; health and environmental services which reduce the costs of health to individuals but require some individual response, e.g. clean water; and, lastly, an array of individual characteristics, including both income, which affects health through food consumption and housing, and education, which affects the speed and efficiency with which individuals respond to health and environmental services. Past and Future Fertility Iecline A fertility decline relies almost entirely on a change in the behavior of individuals, and in contrast to mortality, fertility decline has thus always been assumed to be closely associated with "development." But here what is actually meant by development is important. It was once assumed that structural changes associated with development -- urbanization, industrialization, the shift from family to factory production, and the attainment of income levels close to those of the West -- were a prerequisite to fertility decline; declines in the 1960s that were largely confined to the industrializing economies of Taiwan, Korea (Republic of), Singapore and Hong Kong seemed to confirm this view. But fertility declines beginning in other developing countries in the late 1960s and spreading to more in the 1970s have moved ahead of "development," where development is considered primarily in terms of macrostructural change. 2/ Two noncompeting explanations for the shift in the relationship seem important. First, and important from the point of view of policy, is that fertility declines are related to a different definition of "development," one defined in terms of the standard of living -- levels of literacy, life expectancy and the average incomes of the poorest half of the population -- rather than with the macro changes conventionally associated with develop- ment, such as higher average incomes and a shift to an industrial society. Future Population Growth The World bank has developed a set of projections of world popu- lation by country; these projections are summarized in Table 17 of the World Development Indicators. 1/ There the projected population in the year 2000 is shown by country along with the assumed year in which fertility will reach replacement level, and for each country, the year in which the population will stop growing. In this section we describe the assumptions which underlie the projections, and their implications in terms of future population growth. For selected countries, we present alternative projections and explain what changes in the assumptions underlie the alternatives. These projections and the alternatives should be viewed as illustra- tions of what could happen, not as predictions. There are two conceptually distinct sources of uncertainty regarding future population growth and size. One is common to all predictions of future human behavior. Though the accumulation of evidence from careful studies makes us reasonably certain of the direction of change in fertility and mortality, given certain other changes -- we can be less sure about the magnitude of change; over time, shifts may occur in the relative importance of one or another factor, and in the strength of the relationship between a factor and individual behavior. The second source of uncertainty is more vexing, but a source of optimism as well. The factors which affect fertility are not changing at an immutable rate; governments can take conscious steps to increase more rapidly educa- tional opportunities; to publicly support a change in the status of women; to step up the pace at which health and family planning services are provided. Unpredicted changes in policy may cause unpredicted demographic change. The Assumptions Behind the Projections These projections are based on a simple assumption about the future, namely that current rates of social and economic progress, in- cluding the spread of family planning and of other health and education services, will continue. On that basis, a set of stylized assumptions regarding patterns of demographic change is applied across all countries; these are explained in the Technical Notes accompanying the World Development Indicators. In any country -- not just those for which we present specific alternative projections -- a major departure from expected rates of progress would probably alter the rates of decline in fertility and mortality. For example, slower income growth or slower progress in education would lower the rates of decline; initiation of a major effort in family planning where it has not yet occurred would increase the rates of decline. It is notable that for every country, some future decline in both fertility and mortality is assumed. There are several reasons: (1) The experience of the West and of an increasing number of developing countries is that reductions in mortality are eventually followed by reductions in fertility. 1/ Annex to the World Bank 1980 World Development Report.
 - 73 - Some reduction in mortality has already occurred every- where; that fertility will follow is consistent with classical demographic transition theory. (2) Moreover, across countries and within countries, as discussed in preceding sections, demographic rates are generally lower the higher the level of socioeconomic development. The projections assume that these cross- section differences will apply over time; they assume that the pace of income growth and of socioeconomic change, already captured in current demographic rates across countries, will continue at similar rates within countries and will continue to affect in the same way future demographic rates. Put another way, the future rates of decline in both mortality and fertility are in part a function of current levels. (3) At the same time, as we have discussed above, the pace of declLnes in fertility has quickened. The projec- tions thierefore do not exclude the possibility of a shift downward in the relationship between education, urbanization and other development indicators, and fertility. For example, Indonesia is projected to have achieved a crude birth rate of 25 per thousand by the year 2000, below Costa Rica's current rate of 28 per thousand. But to "match" Costa Rica's current profile in other respects, Indonesia would have to in- crease per capita income from $300 to over $1,000, in- crease life expectancy from 48 to 70, and increase the adult literacy rate from 62 to almost 90 percent -- all in a 20-year period during which its population will increase by 50 percent, from 140 to over 200 million. Two mechanisms build in this downward shift. One is that future country rates are based partly on recent rates; in some countries, including Indonesia, recent rates are lower than cross-section multivariate analyses of fertility determinants alone would indicate. The second is that family planning programs are expected to have an additional effect in reducing fertility, partic- ularly in countries like Mexico and Indonesia, where major program efforts are recent and should have an impact in the next several decades. The projections, in short, assume that economic growth and social progress will continue at the historical pace, reducing fertility and mortal- ity; that fertility will decline somewhat more rapidly in response to these changes than it did in the past; and that family planning programs will affect the pace of declines.

On the one hand, there is room for continuation of current declines in such countries via a transfer of an in- creasing portion of the decline to the less-privileged groups with current high rates.  - 84 - A Concluding Remark There are many reasons to expect poverty and rapid population growth to be mutually reinforcing; these I have tried to outline above. Regarding some of the links, there is substantial evidence; regarding others, much less. The issue is not a simple one; indeed if it were there would be no issue at all. So the search for better understanding goes on; in scientific work the search is for systematic regularities and the framing and testing of refutable hypotheses regarding those regularities. This "science" of eco- nomic demography is impersonal -- concerned, as is evident above, with large numbers, generalizable phenomena, statistical regularities, and theories to explain it all. But policies, or nonpolicies, developed and justified on the basis of such science, concern peculiarly personal subjects -- the family, human reproduction, relations between the young and old, between men and women. Those who bring science to these personal realms tread a peculiar path, one where scientific objectivity is more elusive than ever. But the path is one which commands our attention; population and poverty are not subjects to be ignored. With that in mind the above was written.

doc.repnme: Population and poverty in the developing world
doc.abstracts: The association between poverty and rapid population growth in developing countries is examined. Analysis of current demographic data revealed a shift in the association between low income and high fertility and mortality rates. It is noted that the effects of rapid population growth upon the poor operate at the national level by influencing factor and product prices and the per capita availability of investment resources. Theories of the relation between family size and family members' health and educational and income status are reviewed. Population policy is assessed emphasizing the importance of the delivery of family planning services to the poor. Illustrative projections of population growth into the 21st century are based on a set of assumptions regarding the future course of growth and poverty alleviation and the future family planning policies of developing countries.
